title: Error while running R/readTems.R
body:
Hi, 
Whilst running the readTems function I received this error message: 

Error in dimnames(specimens)[[3]] <- dnames[[1]] : 
  length of 'dimnames' [3] not equal to array extent

The code I ran was the following:
readTems("[...]", semi.landmarks = 0, analyse = TRUE, method = "broken-stick")
It says it has found 145 Tem files - but next above error message is shown. 

Does anyone know what is wrong with the code I am running or the data I put in?

Thanks in advance!
Tobias

title: How to deal with the attributes
body:
#2 related to this issue. @ajhmohr 

```unique_vals <- sort(unique(rawdata[,theCol]))
unique_desc <- unique_vals
# TODO: get unique_desc from attributes if they exist
```

Currently we pulling from the raw data and then saving in attribute_storage. This resets to raw data if you change columns and come back (re-editing). Instead we should populate attribute_storage on the raw data load, and pull the levels tables from attribute storage to edit. 

So function that takes attribute storage and turns it in to the attributes for the original data to create .Rdata output (which can be used for json, etc.).

using Chrome Version 67.0.3396.99 on Mac

title: setup on localhost
body:
Thanks for supplying the code for this, and the work you put into it! I've used JPsychoMorph in our lab for years, so naturally I was/am excited to try this version.

I am trying to setup an instance of webmorph on my local machine (macOS Mojave) and ran into a bit of an issue. I followed the instructions on your README and everything appeared to work, but when I go to `webmorph.test` or `localhost` my browser takes me to a webpage that simply states "It works!". When I add `:8080` it takes me to the tomcat webpage stating it was successfully installed. I'm not a web developer, so this is fairly new to me. I'm just curious if I overlooked a step, or missed something that might be an easy fix since you went though this before.

I did notice that I am running an newer version of `php` than what you mention in your docs (7.x vs 5.x), though I'm not sure that should matter?

title: Power Simulations with Pilot Data
body:
Hi Lisa, 

To start, great package! I have pilot data that I am trying to run power simulations on. Because I am not simulating data I tweaked your `my_lmer_power` function incorporating some simR functions: 
```
my_lmer_power<-function(...) {
# ... is a shortcut that forwards any arguments to my_sim_data()
mode3<-simr::extend(fit, along="subject", n=30) # increase sample size from 5 to 30 
mod_sim <- lmer(aggbaseline ~ cueing + (1|subject), data = getData(mode3), REML=FALSE)
fixef(mod_sim)["cueing"]<-.01 # SESOI I want to run power simulations on with data. 
broom.mixed::tidy(mod_sim)
}
```

When I go to simulate the data sets, it simulates the same dataset 100 times. 
```
reps <- 100
sims <- purrr::map_df(1:reps, ~my_lmer_power())
write_csv(sims, "sims.csv")
```
Any clue what I am doing wrong? Any help would be appreciated. 

Jason 


```

Issue seems to happen only on Firefox and Safari, can edit question in Chrome no problem.

title: Underscores in mu column names doesn't seem to work
body:
When I try to set up a design like so:

```
between <- list(condition = c(control = "Control", 
  low_choice = "Low choice", high_choice = "High choice"))
within <- list(time = c("Pre-essay", "Post-essay"))

mu <- data.frame(
  control     = c(2, 2),
  low_choice  = c(2, 3),
  high_choice = c(2, 5),
  row.names = within$time
)

df <- sim_design(within, between, 
  n = 100, mu = mu, sd = 2, r = .5,
  empirical = TRUE, plot = TRUE)
```

I get the error that the means data table is misspecified. I think it's because of the underscores in the data frame names of mu.

title: transposed mu data.frame
body:
Bug found by @doomlab

```
library(faux)

between <- list(where_bought = c(online = "online", store = "Store"),
                who_bought = c(different = "Different", same = "Same"))
within <- list(rm_var = c("money", "time"))
how_many <- 100

# doesn't work
mu <- data.frame(
  online = c(25, 2),
  store = c(35, 10),
  different = c(25, 1.5),
  same = c(35, 12),
  row.names = within$rm_var
)

# does work!?
mu2 <- t(mu)
               
lab4_update <- sim_design(within, between, n = how_many, mu = mu2,
                          sd = 3, r = .10,
                          empirical = FALSE, plot = TRUE)
```

title: trunc2norm requires both min and max values
body:
If you attempt to run `trunc2norm` with the default values for min and max you receive the following error:

```
Error in truncnorm::ptruncnorm(x, a = min, b = max, mean = mu, sd = sd) : 
  promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems?
```
Using the example from the vignette (without the parameters) will generate the error:
```
x <- truncnorm::rtruncnorm(10000, 1, 7, 3.5, 2)
y <- trunc2norm(x)
```
If you attempt to declare just min or just max parameters (and not both) you will receive the error.

In addition, when I attempted to run with both min/max included with a min of 0, I still received values at -Inf in return.

Sample usage that generated the -Inf values below, where df is a data.frame of numeric values:
`df_trunc <- as.data.frame(sapply(df, trunc2norm, min = 0, max = 4))`

https://github.com/debruine/faux/blob/a5e914b178b6b66d40c30460d41d43b7b8ee2f8b/R/distribution_convertors.R#L147

p.s. This is a wonderful R package!! Thank you for making it.

title: Data Generating Code in Extended Binomial Vignette?
body:
Hi Lisa!

Fantastic manuscript and really useful resource. Just a quick question - I could be entirely wrong here, but is there an error in the extended binomial simulation vignette?

https://github.com/debruine/lmem_sim/blob/eb25e36b7bf80a05cabc72e68ea06981b8791f8d/vignettes/appendix3b_extended_binomial.Rmd#L149-L153

I would have assumed that `B_e = beta_e + S_e + I_e`, and `B_c = beta_c + S_c`. But perhaps there's some simple algebraic reason (relating to the interaction?) that this simulation code works?

title: Using sim_df with missing data goes bork
body:
So, if I use `sim_df` with missing data, it does not like that. You can find my example data `midterm` in my learnSTATS package here: https://github.com/doomlab/learnSTATS/tree/master/data

Then I was trying to do this:

```
    midterm <- sim_df(data = midterm, #data frame
                      n = sample(50:100, 1),#how many of each group
                      between = c("JOL_group", "type_cue"))
```

I think the solution may be to include `na.rm` in this section ... if that makes sense for simulating. I ended up using `na.omit` on my data for what I was doing, then your `messy` function to add the missingness back in. 

```
z <- rnorm_multi(
      n = n,
      vars = ncol(y),
      mu = sapply(y, mean, na.rm = T),
      sd = sapply(y, sd, na.rm = T),
      r = cor(y),
      varnames = names(y),
      empirical = empirical
    )
```

body:
"Currently, our model assumes that each and every subject is exactly 80 ms faster to categorize emotions on in-group faces than on out-group faces" 80 ms should be 50 ms

body:
Forgive me if this is the wrong channel for this, I've not used github very much. I'm getting an error when trying to install. I first installed devtools, and then ran the command: 

"devtools::install_github("debruine/lmem_sim")"

I was asked to update packages, which I did, and then got this error. I can't seem to find a way around it:

"Error: Failed to install 'lmem.sim' from GitHub: System command 'R' failed, exit status: 1, stdout + stderr: E> * checking for file ‘/private/var/folders/bs/q0lxt28s393bjs4ttm2fqb5c0000gn/T/RtmpgDIZuW/remotes12310627baefa/debruine-lmem_sim-2b8a55a/DESCRIPTION’ ... OK E> * preparing ‘lmem.sim’: E> * checking DESCRIPTION meta-information ... OK E> Warning in grepl(e, files, perl = TRUE, ignore.case = TRUE) : E> PCRE pattern compilation error E> 'quantifier does not follow a repeatable item' E> at '*~' E> Error in grepl(e, files, perl = TRUE, ignore.case = TRUE) : E> invalid regular expression '*~' E> Execution halted"

I'm using R version 4.0.3 on a macbook.

title: filenames containing plus sign +
body:
Hi Lisa,
I found an interesting bug today. If a file contains a plus sign in its filename during upload, the file content is depicted as empty in Webmorph (the preview also does not work). Also, after downloading it from Webmorph and opening it locally, the problem persists. 
It probably has to do with plus signs in the browser being used as special characters. Therefore, when parsing file names during upload, plus signs should probably be replaced with underscores (as is already performed for whitespaces).
Best regards,
Mario

title: Shortcuts on Windows
body:
Dear Dr. DeBruine
I've been using webmorph for my placement and am using it now for my dissertation. An issue I've encountered repeatedly is that I'm unable to use the shortcuts with my computer (windows, and non-English keyboard). Right now I'm stuck with trying to add a new point to my template. I found out that I need to press Ctrl+Shift for the "click to add a point" to appear, but when I click, no new point is created. Some options can be accessed from the drop-down menu, but not all options are available that way.
Thanks a lot,
Ronja

title: Error using rnorm_multi()
body: Womp — sorry, this issue came up due to trying to use the function with a supplied matrix that wasn't positive definite; I ended up using an empirical correlation matrix and that solved it.

title: question: How to simulate correlated difference scores?
body:
Hi,

First off — thank you for creating this package! Would you be able to answer my question about simulating correlated difference scores?

To perform power analysis, I want to simulate two sets of scores with their differences correlated. 

There are two tests, x and y, administered at time points 1 and 2:
- x1 and x2 are scores on test x administered at times 1 and 2, respectively
- y1 and y2 are scores on test y administered at times 1 and 2, respectively

Given some arbitrary values of x1 and some correlations between:
- x1 and x2,
- x1 and y1,

I want to simulate data where (x2 - x1) and (y2 - y1) are correlated, with the correlation equal to some corr_deltas.

Could you please tell me if this is possible to do using your package and how to go about it?

Thanks!
— Maciej
